ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Concealable strain sensing method for art preservation

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: A novel method to measure strain without mediation of stress has been developed to assess relative displacements in art objects responding to environmental fluctuations. The method uses a chip with a variable resistor composed of a Giant Magnetic Resistance (GMR) material. In a case study, the dimensional changes of wooden test vehicles subjected to sudden humidity changes at constant temperature inside a controlled environmental chamber were measured. Furthermore, an optimized sensor deployment and converging algorithm to increase the accuracy of the measurements was developed and applied.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Sensing crack appearance and propagation in structural materials is vital for a large variety of industries [1, 2], and this need has generated many types of strain probes and sensing platforms [3–5]. In most cases, though, the cohesive strength of the material is such that measurements can be made utilizing suitable piezoelectric sensors [3, 6]. However, because the latter kind have a large elastic modulus, a large shear stress is associated with the strain measurement, and thus, they are not well suited for assessing strain in art objects made of materials such as wood or textiles, which tend to have lower elastic moduli than those of the piezoelectric materials [7, 8]. Thus, it would be desirable to have a sensor capable of measuring displacement without intermediation of a stress/strain relationship for measuring environmental strain changes in wood and also for gravitational and hygroscopically-induced stresses on the support liners of tapestry.

Previously, Differential Variable Reluctance Transducers (DVRT) sensors were used in structural health monitoring of concrete infrastructure [9] and of wood [10, 11] based on impedance change produced by movement of electro-mechanically coupled pieces. The disadvantages of the latter kind of sensors for monitoring wooden cultural heritage objects is that they need a complex and sometimes bulky mechanical holding structure which may not be optimal for monitoring wooden cultural heritage objects while being exhibited. Moreover, those with high sensitivity require ac voltage and consume a relatively large amount of power requiring also a cable connection between sensor and power supply [10, 11]. Nevertheless, they have been used by conservation scientists in order to understand the effect of environmental fluctuations on art objects [10, 11].

There is a novel type of low power sensors, miniature in size, that are suitable for the purpose of measuring strain without intermediation of a stress/strain relationship. They are based on a chip which contains a resistance bridge with a variable resistance elements composed of a GMR material and their performance will be ascertained in this article.
A great deal of work has been produced by conservation scientists using a variety of techniques to understand the effect of environmental fluctuations in art objects [12–18].

It will be shown in this article that the properties and small size of the GMR sensors position them to play an important role in complementing other non-destructive techniques, such as acoustic emission [13, 19, 20], used to study wooden objects by conservation scientists.

The GMR sensors used in this study have a small-form factor and are very power-efficient, ideally to be integrated with wireless monitoring where power is provided by batteries. The sensors have been developed by NVE corporation and are commercially available [21]. In this article, a method is described which utilizes these GMR sensors to measure three-dimensional relative displacements in objects such as wood or textiles, which is suitable for integrating object deformation measurements with environmental information.

Section1.Heading: Experimental
Section1.Para:
To measure strain, the displacement between a GMR sensor and a small magnet is tracked, where the sensor and magnet are mounted on separate holders and are mechanically decoupled. The method allows to measure displacement of substrates that have elastic modulus much smaller than solid state materials. Figure 1 describes the GMR sensor–magnet configuration. The sensor chosen for the experiment has a linear output between 1.5 and 11.5 Oersted, and an operating temperature range of −50 to
125
∘
C
$125~^{\circ}\mbox{C}$ [21]. In the preferred mode of operation, the field is provided by a small rare earth magnet positioned with its axis aligned to the axis of sensitivity of the GMR element. The properties described above underscore the advantage of this type of sensor in that, after suitable calibration of sensor output voltage vs. relative displacement, the relative motion between chip and magnet can be measured.
Fig. 1
Photo of the GMR chip–magnet configuration

For calibrations experiments the chip was mounted in fix location, while the magnet was aligned with the chip axis of sensitivity on a platform with micrometer displacements in the three axes. The chip was powered with a 3.2 DC voltage, and the voltage output vs. magnet position was recorded with a 0.1 mV resolution. The magnetic field is generated by a rare-earth magnet of 3.2 mm length and 1.6 mm diameter that is mounted on a 3D stage controlled by micrometers that has a displacement accuracy of 2.5 μm. Although the chip has higher sensitivity for the maximum accepted voltage input of 5 V, it was powered at 3.2 V for reasons that will be explained later in the discussion in connection with their being incorporated into a wireless sensor network.

Figure 2 shows the calibration of the chip voltage output

For the calibration and experiment the chip was surrounded laterally by a μ metal cylinder to avoid cross-talking between sensors positioned in close proximity, but oriented perpendicularly to one another. The typical sensor output voltage Vs distance has a variable sensitivity to the total magnetic flux in the direction of the axis of sensitivity. To simplify the calculations, the voltage variation due to lateral displacement is assumed constant with an absolute value equal to that of a 0.3-cm lateral displacement. Because the latter value varies slightly along the sensor–magnet distance, an average was taken of the values at the beginning, mid value and end of the linear region shown in Fig. 2. Having determined the calibration parameters for the particular chip and magnet arrangement described above, two wooden objects of different shape and kind were selected to test the performance of the sensors. Object 1 was a piece of cedar 8-mm-thick cut along the fibers and which had an incipient crack. Object 2 was a piece of pine 20-mm-thick which was cut across the fiber, exposing the growth rings. In order to assess the effect of lateral displacements, the node is defined as described in Fig. 4a, which shows a schematic representation of the way three identical sensors are deployed in object 1. In object 2 the
x
$x$ direction is the radial direction, and thus the
y
$y$ direction is tangential to the ring at the insertion of the sensor in direction
x
$x$ . In addition, a control setup was deployed where both the chip and magnet were attached to a glass slide. The actual orientation of the sensor and magnet mounting is shown in Fig. 4b.
Fig. 4
a Schematic representation of the way a measuring node is assembled on the wood object 1. b A photograph (top view) of the actual wooden objects

Section1.Heading: Results
Section1.Para:
The two wooden objects with mounted strain sensors and corresponding magnets were placed in a regulated temperature-humidity chamber. The chamber was run so that the temperature was kept constant at
25
∘
C
$25~^{\circ}\mbox{C}$ and the relative humidity (RH) was abruptly ramped from 50 to 85 %, a process that took about 20 min. The GMR sensors outputs were sampled every 30 s. After 48 h, the RH was reversed down to 50 %. The raw data for the ramping up for the first 25 h for object 1, which is what it took for the data to reach a plateau, is plotted in Fig. 5a. The data for the ramping down experiment were collected for 96 h, however the values reached a plateau, with exception of those of the sensor in the
x
$x$ direction for object 1 (across the crack) after about 30 h, and the corresponding data are plotted in Fig. 5b. The data for object 2 are shown in Fig. 5c and d, respectively. The readings of the control sensor (not shown in Fig. 5) fluctuated only within
± 0.1
mV
${\pm} 0.1\ \mbox{mV}$ throughout the experiment and we took this fluctuation as our precision value. As for the accuracy of the results, they are limited by both the calibration and the chip output to the (magnet-dependent) magnetic field. Then, from the calibration output and the precision, an error of
± 4
μm
was assumed to our measurements. This value compares well with the micron resolution indicated by DVRT sensors [10]. For the sensors oriented along the
y
$y$ and
z
$z$ axes, the plateau had the same values as those of time zero, whereas the plateau for the sensor along the
x
$x$ axis (across the crack) was reached after 50 h, and its value was slightly lower than that of time zero.
Fig. 5
Output variation vs. time for relative humidity variation from 50 to 85 % for object 1 (a) and object 2 (c) and relative humidity change from 85 to 50 % for object 1 (b) and object 2 (d)

The voltage reads in the three orthogonally positioned sensors shown in Fig. 5 reflect both a displacement along their axis of sensitivity and a displacement perpendicular to it. Therefore, the conversion of voltages to actual displacements in each coordinate is a non-linear one. However from Eqs. (2), (3) and (4), the voltage variation for displacements in the direction perpendicular to the axis of sensitivity of the sensor is less than 1 order of magnitude than that of the displacements parallel to said axis, the ratio being 0.06. Thus, zero-order displacement data for direction obtained using Eq. (1) needs a correction.
An iterative method for correction of the zero-order data was developed and used to mitigate the non-linear effects described above.

Fig. 6
Relative displacement along the three axes for 0, 1, and 2 correction iterations, for relative humidity excursion from 50 to 85 % for object 1 (a) and object 2 (c) and relative humidity change from 85 to 50 % object 1 (b) and object 2 (d)

To assess the reversibility of the process, the calculated displacements at the beginning and end of a set of two consecutive runs are shown in Table 1. The results of Figs. 5 and 6 and of Table 1 indicate that for object 1 the deformation is mostly reversible within the time frame of the experiment, with exception of the crack opening, which exhibits an increase of about 15 % of its maximum incursion, after the RH goes back to its initial value at the end of the second run, and it may be the consequence of larger timescale hysteretic behavior. A more detailed experiment will be necessary to determine the latter against an irreversible deformation.

Although the objective of this work is not to make a detailed study to predict the deformation of wood upon changes in RH, it is interesting to point out that by selectively positioning sensors in different growth rings, estimating and computing Eq. (12) allows for a better modeling of the deformation of this kind of objects. The results shown above demonstrate the usefulness of the sensors assembly and correction methods to study in detail the deformation of certain class of objects. It should be emphasized that the conditions of the experimental T/RH chamber mimic a possible interruption of the well-controlled conditions in a museum environment on a humid day.

The above results in our experimental pieces also imply that the response of the objects to a sudden change in RH may be relatively fast, less than one hour. Furthermore, the behavior of the crack opening in object 1 also demonstrate the usefulness of this scheme to model long-term effect of environmental fluctuations for art object. The above results, and the sensor characteristics (concealment because of small size, stress-independent, low-energy consumption) are a demonstration of the advantages that the described assembly offers in terms of monitoring wood or textile objects, in situ in a museum, compared to previously used sensors in these venues [1]. A further advantage is that our sensors are well suited to be powered by small batteries and embedded as part of remotely controlled radio elements (motes), capable to also carry environmental sensing combined with power-efficient communication based on time-synchronized communication protocol.

One such implementation is the Low Power Wireless Mote Technology (LPMT) developed in IBM that is based on a mesh network utilizing time synchronized communication. Multiple sensors can be attached to the motes that are relevant to assess the microenvironment fluctuations: temperature, humidity, air contamination, door position, presence sensors, etc. The sensor data can be acquired independently of triggered sensor data (to asses for example how the presence of one person would change the local relative humidity value around objects of art). The sensor network is characterized by low-power and small-form factor sensors that can be attached to objects of art in a concealable way. Deformation data of wooden objects could be correlated in real time with environmental fluctuations and feed thus analytical predictive models based on detailed measurements on the wood response to environment [22–25]. Furthermore, continuous monitoring could provide an in situ testing vehicle for the goal of reaching a common understanding of standards [26–28].

Figure 7 illustrates a possible deployment of the sensors with the mote on the backside of an actual wood carving which allows concealed continuous strain monitoring with correlations to environmental fluctuations measured by the same platform.
Fig. 7
Sensor array and mote installed on the back of a rare carving from Transylvania

Section1.Heading: Summary
Section1.Para: The versatility of GMR sensors to monitor small displacements with micron resolution, and without the intervention of a stress/strain tensor relationship, has been demonstrated. The sensors and setup are particularly useful for sensing, under concealment, distortions in wooden and textile cultural heritage objects, which makes them suitable for integrating long-temporal-range object deformation measurements with environmental information. Furthermore, an iterative method that corrects for non-linear effects has been tested and shown to rapidly converge, allowing for an improved accuracy in the monitoring of wood deformation.

Acknowledgments.Heading: Acknowledgements
Acknowledgments.SimplePara: The authors will like to thank Michael Gaynes for technical assistance with the temperature–humidity chamber, and also Marco Leona, Paolo Dionisi Vici, Masahiko Tsukada and Lucretia Kargere for useful discussions.
